title: The Edinburgh gazetteer, or geographical dictionary ...
snippet: Cause-wayside-street, New-street, and Storie-street, run in a southerly direction fromHigh-street, and are very closely built ; asare also the following : Moss-street, whichruns north from the cross into St James'sPlace ; St James's-street, Old Sneddon-street, and New Sneddon-street, all lyingnorth of High-street, and the last of whichpushes out a very considerable distance tothe northward, as Causeway side- street doesto the southward of the main body of thetown. The principal street of the NewTown is composed of elegant modern houses,and continues the main line of street, fromthe east end of the Old Bridge, till itmerges in the Glasgow road. From bothsides of this street several others strike offat different angles, and are again crossed atsome distance by others ; all the streetsin this part of the town being compactlybuilt, and fully inhabited.

title: The Edinburgh gazetteer, or geographical dictionary ...
snippet: Tlie Old Town consistschiefly of twelve principal streets, althoughthere are in it many others of minor importance. Of the leading streets, three,namely High-street, George-street, and Canal-street, run from east to west, and areof very great length, especially High-street, which cemmencing at the Old Bridge,is continued with a curvature for morethan a mile, ere it terminates on theroad to Beith. At the cross, this street isformed into an area of considerable extent,.bordered by excellent houses and shops, andadorned by the fronts of two handsomepublic structures, the town-house and thecoffee-room buildings.

title: The Edinburgh gazetteer, or geographical dictionary ...

title: Flying visits,

title: John and Betty's Scotch history visit,
author: Williamson, Margaret. [from old catalog]
snippet: *' There's the tall Wallace Monument/' said Mrs. Pitt, " and the Old Bridge of Stirling, built about 1410, and for centuries the only gateway to the Highlands ; near it Wallace won his greatest victory over the English in September, 1297. It was under that bridge, too, Betty, that David and Allan, in ^ Kidnapped,'  hid when they had at length ventured down from the mountains.

title: Europe from May to December,
author: Williams, Rudolph.
snippet: and in which there is a hall where they sight. We walked over what is called the Old Bridge, and saw the Gasthaus. The mistress told us that the rules were they should sight fifty minutes, unless, before the expiration of that time, one of the combatants should be wounded severely enough to withdraw, or, in the opinion of the surgeon and umpire, to appease the wrath of the opponent.

title: Scotland Picturesque and Traditional. A pilgrimage with staff and knapsack

author: Hargreaves, Thomas
snippet: Here Byron says he used often to lean, with suchdelight when a boy, that the recollection of it in afteryears was a source of infinite pleasure to him. Onthe road from the New to the Old Bridge a long rowof fishermen's cottages are passed. These are a betterbuilt style of cott.ages than those usually occupied bythis tribe of men.

title: The British isles through an opera glass,
author: Taylor, Charles M.
snippet: The Royal Victoria Hotel — Ross Castle — To the Gap — Kate Kearney's Cottage — Fairy Glen — Serpent Lake — St. Patrick's Cottage — Macgillicuddy's Reeks — Five Islands — The Long Range — " The Happy Family" — Shooting the Rapids — The Old Bridge — Toothache Bridge — Bricken Bridge — Devil's Island — Muckross Abbey — Colleen Bawn Rock — Tore Mountain — Limerick — The Theatre Royal — River Shannon — Kilrush.
